Photo by Mike Shea/Tritone Photography | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = David Ramos | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|1|13|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Fullerton, California]], [[United States]] | death_date = | death_place = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Electric blues]], [[blues rock]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1980–present | label = [[Black Top Records|Black Top]], [[Evidence Records|Evidence]] | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Kid Ramos''' (born January 13, 1959) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[blues rock]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.{{cite web|author=Greg Prato |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/kid-ramos-mn0000072335/biography |title=Kid Ramos | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1959-01-13 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} Ramos has released four solo albums since 1995 on [[Black Top Records|Black Top]] and [[Evidence Records]]. He has worked with [[James Harman]], [[Roomful of Blues]], the Big Rhythm Combo, [[The Fabulous Thunderbirds]], [[The Mannish Boys]], [[Bobby Jones (singer)|Bobby Jones]] and Los Fabulocos. ==Life and career== '''David Ramos''' was born in [[Fullerton, California]], [[United States]], with both of his parents being professional opera singers. After playing at the parties of friends and at local [[nightclub]]s in his teenage years, he turned fully professional when joining [[James Harman]]'s band in 1980. He stayed playing his guitar for Harman until 1988, when he briefly helped out with [[Roomful of Blues]]. However, at this point, Ramos took a break from music to raise a family, and worked as a water delivery man. In 1994, Ramos joined forces with [[Lynwood Slim]] to form the Big Rhythm Combo. Ramos' debut solo album, ''Two Hands One Heart'', was released the following year. Ramos had joined [[The Fabulous Thunderbirds]] in 1993, following an invitation from their singer, [[Kim Wilson]]. As well as regularly recording and appearing with them up to 2002, Ramos also continued to release his own albums, with ''Greasy Kid Stuff'' (2001) being his most recent. Ramos appeared at the 2005 [[Edmonton's Labatt Blues Festival]], playing along with [[the Mannish Boys]]. He also formed the roots quartet, [[Los Fabulocos]], who released their debut album in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://deltagrooveproductions.com/music/artists/losfabulocos/main.html |title=Los Fabulocos |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |accessdate=2012-12-08}} In 2009, Ramos backed [[Bobby Jones (singer)|Bobby Jones]] at the [[Notodden Blues Festival]]. In August 2012, Ramos was diagnosed with [[Ewing's sarcoma]],{{cite web|url=https://www.blues.org|title=The Kid Ramos Bob Corritore Phoenix Blues Sessions|publisher=The Blues Foundation|accessdate=2012-12-08}} a rare form of cancer, and underwent chemotherapy treatment the following month. He is expected to require radiotherapy, surgery and further chemotherapy during the course of the next year and a medical appeal has been launched to assist with the costs of his treatment. Kid Ramos received the Orange County Music Awards Lifetime Achievement Award March 7, 2014. At the event he announced that he had completed his treatment and recovered from the cancer. {{cite web|url=http://www.deltagrooveproductions.com/music/kid.html?ref=nf |title=Donate & Send Healing Thoughts To Guitarist Kid Ramos |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-08}} ==Discography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
